result.story: The drink is named after London's Buck's Club where it was invented as an excuse to begin drinking early; it was first served in 1921 by a barman named McGarry. The drink was named in honor of the premiere of Rob Roy, an operetta by composer Reginald De Koven and lyricist Harry B. Smith loosely based upon Scottish folk hero Robert Roy MacGregor. The Rob Roy is similar to a Manhattan but is made exclusively with Scotch whisky, while the Manhattan is traditionally made with rye.

result.story: Henry C. Ramos invented the Ramos Gin Fizz in 1888 at his bar, the Imperial Cabinet Saloonin on Gravier Street, New Orleans, Louisiana. It was originally called the New Orleans Fizz, and is one of the city's most famous cocktails. Before Prohibition, the bar was known to have over 20 bartenders working at once, making nothing but the Ramos Gin Fizz - and still struggling to keep up with the demand. During the carnival of 1915, 32 staff were on at once, just to shake the drink. The drink's long mixing time (12 minutes) made it a very time consuming cocktail to produce.
result.name: Ramos Fizz

result.story: Although different variations of coffee cocktails pre-date the now-classic Irish coffee by at least 100 years, the original Irish coffee was according to sources invented and named by Joe Sheridan, a head chef at Foynes, County Limerick but originally from Castlederg, County Tyrone. Foynes' port was the precursor to Shannon International Airport in the west of Ireland; the coffee was conceived after a group of American passengers disembarked from a Pan Am flying boat on a miserable winter evening in the 1940s. Sheridan added whiskey to the coffee to warm the passengers. After the passengers asked if they were being served Brazilian coffee, Sheridan told them it was "Irish coffee".
result.name: Irish Coffee

result.story: The Frozen Margarita has many a story about its origins. While the history is a little icy, one thing that’s history is solid is when the Frozen Margarita machine was invented, which was May 11, 1971, by restaurant owner Mariano Martinez. Basically a converted soft-serve ice cream machine, the original machine is on display at the Smithsonian National Museum of History. Some other facts include: the Margarita was the "Drink of the Month" in Esquire magazine in December of 1953, and further popularized by the Jimmy Buffett song "Margaritaville".
result.name: Frozen Margarita

result.story: The Long Island Iced Tea is a classic combination of four different spirits.  Dating back to the 70s, where it was invented for a cocktail competition in, surprise surprise, Long Island in New York. Although it doesn’t actually contain any tea, the look and taste of the cocktail contributed to its name and rise in popularity as the ultimate drink in disguise.

result.story: The Sea Breeze was traces its heritage back to the 1950s, when vodka’s popularity increased exponentially. According to Imbibe Magazine, only 40,000 cases of vodka were sold in 1950 in the United States, but by 1955, that number had increased to four million. Another thing that rose to popularity in the 1950s? Cranberry juice. Combine the two, add a dash of grapefruit juice and a wedge of lime, and you’ve got a refreshing cocktail. Grab your sunglasses, because this one is perfect for the summertime.

result.story:
The Vodka Martini dates back to the late 1800s, but as far as we’re concerned, it’s a 1960s drink. With three words—Shaken, not stirred—the Vodka Martini came to be associated with one of the suavest men on Earth, James Bond. A drink perfect for a classy night, in or out.
And while we wouldn’t dare argue with James Bond, we can’t help but point out that a cocktail purist wouldn’t shake their martini, as that would upset the spirit and dilute the drink. You should always treat a vodka martini a little delicately.

result.story: There are few drinks as iconic and with so many variations; the martini comes in all possible flavors. Here is an easy, excellent way to spice up the classic. Grenadine – which by the way is a good bottle to keep around the home bar as it can add a sweet redness to many drinks – and orange bitters give the martini a completely new taste and pink look.

result.story: The Martini gained its classic status in the late 80s. When the popularity of colorful cocktails, especially martinis, took heavy pace as fresh ingredients finally started to find their way into cocktails. Bartenders realized the brilliant potential for vodka when mixed with fresh ingredients, while maintaining a strong alcohol-to-mixer ratio and so the modern martini was created.

result.story:
A pink drink served in a Martini glass and called The Cosmopolitan is
said to have originated in San Francisco in the 1980s, but it wasn't
until 1988--the year Absolut Citron was launched--that the
Cosmopolitan as it is known today was created. Bartender Toby Cecchini
adapted the original recipe, using fresh juice, orange liqueur, a
splash of cranberry, and the first citrus-flavored vodka. The rest is history!

result.story: Along with the Mojito and the Daiquiri, the Cuba Libre shares the mystery of its exact origin. The only certainty is that this cocktail was first sipped in Cuba. The year? 1900. Or maybe before. 1900 is generally said to be the year that cola first came to Cuba, introduced to the island American troops. But “Cuba Libre!” was the battle cry of the Cuba Liberation Army during the war of independence that ended in 1878.
